Thank you for the practical question—it's a fair one.

We do not have a fixed public “round number” at which we automatically stop holding the seat. Our approach is to keep the seat available as long as there remains a realistic possibility that a higher-priority candidate on our list may still apply to School_C in the upcoming rounds (for example, if they are not able to secure a placement at a higher-ranked choice and then turn to us).

That said, as we get closer to the end of the process, we will make a final decision based on the active applicant pool at that time and our priority order. If you would like to remain in consideration, the most helpful step is to continue checking in and be ready to submit an [APPLY] again if/when you decide you want School_C to be your active option in that moment.

I also encourage you to continue pursuing other schools in parallel so you are not left waiting on an outcome that we cannot guarantee.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your continued patience and for reaffirming that School_C is your first choice.

After reviewing our remaining seat and the current stage of the process, we are able to offer you admission. We appreciate your persistence and clear commitment to enrolling if accepted.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on School_C’s true priority list (ahead of Student_C only). Higher-priority candidates are Student_B, Student_A, Student_D. Given students’ preferences: Student_B ranks School_C #2 (after School_E), Student_C ranks School_C #2 (but is lowest on our list), Student_A ranks School_C last, Student_D ranks School_C last. As rounds progress (now round 12/30), the only realistic higher-priority threat is Student_B potentially turning to School_C if rejected by School_E and unable to land School_D/School_B/School_A. Student_A and Student_D are very unlikely to apply to School_C because it is their last choice. Holding the seat too long risks ending unmatched if no one else applies; however, Student_E is actively applying now and is acceptable under our list. Considering the long history of repeated applications and the diminishing likelihood of a higher-priority applicant arriving soon, accepting Student_E now secures a match rather than risking an unfilled seat.
